This does not apply to weddings, funerals, and religious services (including rites and ceremonies) "if the gathering is held in a building or structure other than a private dwelling" or outdoors. UPDATE: Canada, Ontario, July 17, 2020. The Ontario government determines that some health regions within the province are allowed to move to Stage 3 of Ontario's reopening framework. Regions in stage 3 are allowed to hold gatherings of more than 10 people while regions still in stage 2 must adhere to the previous rule of no more than 10 people.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Canada, Ontario, June 12, 2020. The Ontario government determines that outdoor weddings, funerals, and religious services (including rites and ceremonies) can proceed with "no more than 50 people." However, "all persons attending the gathering must remain at least two meters apart from each other ... unless they are members of the same household." There are further exceptions for religious services. UPDATE: Canada, Ontario, July 17, 2020. The Ontario government determines that some health regions within the province are allowed to move to Stage 3 of Ontario's reopening framework. Outdoor weddings, funerals, and religious services within regions in Stage 3 are allowed to proceed with 100 people while regions in Stage 2 must adhere to the previous rule of 50 people.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Can, NB, July 20, 2020 "As per Section 2 of the state of emergency mandatory order, venues at which seating is offered for the purposes of eating, drinking, socialization, celebration, ceremony or entertainment are required to maintain a record of the names and contact information of all persons who attend. The same applies to anyone who hosts, organizes or permits gatherings larger than 50.”
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: All Recreational or commercial events allowed to occur with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
Canada, Ontario, July 17, 2020. The Ontario government determines that within health regions that are in Stage 2 of Ontario's Reopening Framework, all events and social gatherings at private dwellings are restricted to 10 people. The order is slated to last until July 29, 2020.

"The following regions will remain in Stage 2" until further notice: Peel Public Health, Toronto Public Health, and Windsor-Essex County Health Unit.

description:
Canada, Ontario, July 24, 2020. The Ontario government determines that within health regions that are in Stage 2 of Ontario's Reopening Framework, all outdoor weddings, funerals, and religious service are restricted to 50 people. The order is slated to last until July 29, 2020.
The following health regions are affected by this order: Peel Public Health, Toronto Public Health, and Windsor-Essex County Health Unit. UPDATE: Canada, Ontario, July 24, 2020. The Ontario Legislature introduces the Reopening Ontario (A Flexible Response to COVID-19) Act, 2020. In consequence, the previously declared restrictions of gatherings have been extended for 30 days and will thus last until August 22, 2020.

description: Canada, Ontario, June 12, 2020. The Ontario government determines that indoor weddings, funerals, and religious services (including rites and ceremonies) that are being "held in a building or structure other than a private dwelling" can proceed at "30 per cent of the capacity of the particular room." However, "all persons attending the gathering must remain at least two meters apart from each other ... unless they are members of the same household." UPDATE: Canada, Ontario, July 24, 2020. The Ontario Legislature introduces the Reopening Ontario (A Flexible Response to COVID-19) Act, 2020. In consequence, the previously declared restrictions of gatherings have been extended for 30 days and will thus last until August 22, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Canada, Ontario, May 19, 2020. The Ontario government is "allowing drive-in religious gatherings" under conditions. "The conditions include keeping vehicles two metres or more apart, only members of the same household can be in one vehicle, people will not be able to leave their vehicles, and no more than five people can conduct the service at one time from outside a motor vehicle and they must stay at least two metres apart." This order remains in place until May 29, 2020. UPDATE: Canada, Ontario, July 24, 2020. The Ontario Legislature introduces the Reopening Ontario (A Flexible Response to COVID-19) Act, 2020. In consequence, the previously declared restrictions of gatherings have been extended for 30 days and will thus last until August 22, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Canada, Manitoba, July 25, 2020. Indoor gatherings with up to 50 people are allowed without conditions. Faith-based gatherings, stage performances, and movie theaters are exempt from this restriction.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Canada, Manitoba, July 25, 2020. Indoor gatherings with over 50 people "are permitted with a maximum group size of 30 per cent of the site's capacity provided the group can be physically divided into sub-groups of 50 or fewer. Each sub-group must be able to arrive, depart and participate in the gathering without co-mingling with members from any other sub-group. Adequate physical distancing must ... be provided for all participants." Faith-based gatherings, stage performances, and movie theaters are exempt from this restriction.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Canada, Manitoba, July 25, 2020. Phase 4 of Manitoba's Restoring Safe Services eases mass gathering restrictions for faith-based gatherings, "including pow wows and other cultural and spiritual events." These gatherings are allowed with a "maximum of 30 per cent [of the site's capacity] or 500 people, whichever is lower ... Members of the public must be able to reasonably able to maintain a separation of at least two metres from others, except for brief exchanges."

description: Canada, Manitoba, July 25, 2020. Phase 4 of Manitoba's Restoring Safe Services eases mass gathering restrictions for stage performances and movie theaters. These sites may reopen "at a capacity of 30 per cent of the site's capacity or 500 people, whichever is lower ... Physical distancing must be possible between individuals, households and small groups of people travelling to the event together ... Sites must also address physical distancing in areas where patrons may congregate between shows, performances or acts of a play at intermissions."

description: Canada, British Columbia March 16th "We are issuing a new order prohibiting all public gatherings of more than 50 people. This includes indoor and outdoor sporting events, conferences, meetings, religious gatherings and other similar events. " UPDATE: The original restriction was 50 people. The provincial health officer’s order on mass gatherings has been amended to limit the number of people in vacation accommodations, including for house, cabin, yurt and boat rentals, as well as hotel rooms. The number of people is limited to the capacity of the space, plus up to a maximum of five visitors.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Canada, Québec- As of the 23 April "the cancellation of indoor and outdoor festivals and cultural events planned in Québec until August 31, 2020." UPDATE: Festivals of 250 are allowed to happen in the province as of August 3. "The limit of 250 people must be respected at all times and that means organizers who push ahead with their events must be responsible for crowd control at entry and exit points." As well as making sure there is 2 meters between separate households at all times.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Can, NB, Aug 11, 2020 "Yellow Alert Level: Revised measures under Yellow include allowing public venues with seating to reduce physical distancing down to one metre with the continuous use of a mask. This measure already exists when using public transit and will apply starting Monday, Aug. 17 in settings such as theatres or recreational facilities such as arenas with the condition that food and drink not be consumed when people are seated at this distance. Distancing of two metres would be required in order for food or drinks to be consumed"
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Canada, Yukon is now allowing indoor visits at Yukon's long-term care facilities as of August 19. There are still strict guidelines to follow: screening upon entry, mask and hand-sanitizer use, but contact will be permitted.

description: Canada, Ontario, May 19, 2020. The Ontario government is "allowing drive-in religious gatherings" under conditions. "The conditions include keeping vehicles two metres or more apart, only members of the same household can be in one vehicle, people will not be able to leave their vehicles, and no more than five people can conduct the service at one time from outside a motor vehicle and they must stay at least two metres apart." This order remains in place until May 29, 2020. UPDATE: Canada, Ontario, August 20, 2020. "The Ontario government ... is extending orders currently in force under the Reopening Ontario (A Flexible Response to COVID-19) Act, 2020 … to September 22, 2020."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Canada, Ontario, June 12, 2020. The Ontario government determines that indoor weddings, funerals, and religious services (including rites and ceremonies) that are being "held in a building or structure other than a private dwelling" can proceed at "30 per cent of the capacity of the particular room." However, "all persons attending the gathering must remain at least two meters apart from each other ... unless they are members of the same household." UPDATE: Canada, Ontario, August 20, 2020. "The Ontario government ... is extending orders currently in force under the Reopening Ontario (A Flexible Response to COVID-19) Act, 2020 … to September 22, 2020."

description: Canada, Manitoba, August 24, 2020. In the Interlake-Eastern Health region, the Northern Health region, the Southern Health-Santé Sud region, and the Winnipeg Metropolitan Region, indoor gatherings with up to 50 people are allowed without conditions. Faith-based gatherings, stage performances, and movie theaters are exempt from this restriction.

description: Canada, Manitoba, August 24, 2020. In the Interlake-Eastern Health region, the Northern Health region, the Southern Health-Santé Sud region, and the Winnipeg Metropolitan Region, indoor gatherings with over 50 people "are permitted with a maximum group size of 30 per cent of the site's capacity provided the group can be physically divided into sub-groups of 50 or fewer. Each sub-group must be able to arrive, depart and participate in the gathering without co-mingling with members from any other sub-group. Adequate physical distancing must ... be provided for all participants." Faith-based gatherings, stage performances, and movie theaters are exempt from this restriction.

description: Canada, Manitoba, August 24, 2020. In the Interlake-Eastern Health region, the Northern Health region, the Southern Health-Santé Sud region, and the Winnipeg Metropolitan Region, stage performances and movie theaters may open "at a capacity of 30 per cent of the site's capacity or 500 people, whichever is lower ... Physical distancing must be possible between individuals, households and small groups of people travelling to the event together ... Sites must also address physical distancing in areas where patrons may congregate between shows, performances or acts of a play at intermissions."

description: Canada, Manitoba, July 25, 2020. Outdoor gatherings with up to 100 people are allowed without conditions. Faith-based gatherings, stage performances, and movie theaters are exempt from this restriction. UPDATE: Canada, Manitoba, August 24, 2020. The Prairie Mountain Health region moves "to the restricted level according to the #RestartMB Pandemic Response System." As such, public gatherings are "restricted to 10 people, both indoors and outdoors." The remaining four health regions in Manitoba, the Interlake-Eastern Health region, the Northern Health region, the Southern Health-Santé Sud region, and the Winnipeg Metropolitan Region, will continue to follow the previously declared policies.

description: B.C.'s Ministry of Tourism, Arts and Culture said on August 25 that the province is moving to Phase 3 of its sports guidelines, allowing leagues and athletes to participate in organized sports, though cohorts of 10-100 people depending on the sport. Close physical proximity should still be minimized as much as possible, which mean game rules should be modified to keep participants at a safe distance, and organizers should limit the number and duration of contacts between participants when physical distancing isn't possible.

description: The Yukon government released new guidelines Aug. 26 on how residents can return to the ice, field and court for contact sports. description: Canada, Manitoba, September 28, 2020. In the Interlake-Eastern Health region, the Northern Health region, and the Southern Health-Santé Sud region, indoor gatherings with over 50 people "are permitted with a maximum group size of 30 per cent of the site's capacity provided the group can be physically divided into sub-groups of 50 or fewer. Each sub-group must be able to arrive, depart and participate in the gathering without co-mingling with members from any other sub-group. Adequate physical distancing must ... be provided for all participants." Faith-based gatherings, stage performances, and movie theaters are exempt from this restriction.

description: Canada, Manitoba, August 24, 2020. In the Interlake-Eastern Health region, the Northern Health region, the Southern Health-Santé Sud region, and the Winnipeg Metropolitan Region, indoor gatherings with over 50 people "are permitted with a maximum group size of 30 per cent of the site's capacity provided the group can be physically divided into sub-groups of 50 or fewer. Each sub-group must be able to arrive, depart and participate in the gathering without co-mingling with members from any other sub-group. Adequate physical distancing must ... be provided for all participants." Faith-based gatherings, stage performances, and movie theaters are exempt from this restriction. UPDATE: Canada, Manitoba, September 28, 2020. The Winnipeg Metropolitan Region moves to the Restricted level according to the #RestartMB Pandemic Response System. As such, public gatherings are "restricted to 10 people, both indoors and outdoors." The Interlake-Eastern Health region, the Northern Health region, and the Southern Health-Santé Sud region will continue to follow the previously declared policies.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description:
Canada, Manitoba, October 8, 2020. Organized indoor gatherings and events involving more than 50 persons may take place if the number of persons attending does not exceed 30% of the usual capacity of the premises, the premises where the gathering or
event is held is physically divided into separate areas which contain no more than 50 persons each, and persons in each area are prevented from
coming into close proximity with persons in another area during the gathering or event as well as when entering or leaving.

description: Canada, Manitoba announced on October 26 that the maximum size of gatherings is reduced to five people. This applies to ceremonies, social events and informal gatherings. Gatherings involving more than five persons may take place if the number of persons attending does not exceed 30% of the usual capacity of the place or premises where the gathering is held.

description: Canada, Manitoba announced on October 26 that the maximum size of gatherings is reduced to five people. This applies to ceremonies, social events and informal gatherings. Gatherings involving more than five persons may take place if the number of persons attending does not exceed 30% of the usual capacity of the place or premises where the gathering is held. Update 19 November 2020: People are prohibited from assembling in a gathering of more than five people at any indoor or outdoor public place including the common areas of a multi-unit residence, with the exception of a health-care facility or critical business that adheres to health protection measures. UPDATE: people are prohibited from assembling in a gathering of more than five people at any indoor or outdoor public place including the common areas of a multi-unit residence, with the exception of a health-care facility or critical business that adheres to health protection measures.

description:
On Nov 20 2020, NS government, Canada announced new gathering restrictions on gathering limits
-five people can gather in a close social group without physical distancing, down from 10
-a household may have more than five members but they may only go outside the home in groups of five
-households can only have a maximum of five visitors at a time
-onsite gatherings at long-term care facilities can have a maximum of five people (including residents and staff), down from 10
-adult day programs for seniors who live in the community will not be allowed
-25 people, down from 50, can gather with physical distancing for informal indoor and outdoor social events like a neighbourhood street party
-indoor events run by a recognized business or organization can have 50 per cent of the venue’s capacity to 
a maximum of 100 people with physical distancing, down from 200
-outdoor events run by a recognized business or organization can have 150 people with physical distancing, down from 250
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On Nov 20 2020, NS government, Canada announced new gathering restrictions on gathering limits
-five people can gather in a close social group without physical distancing, down from 10
-a household may have more than five members but they may only go outside the home in groups of five
-households can only have a maximum of five visitors at a time
-onsite gatherings at long-term care facilities can have a maximum of five people (including residents and staff), down from 10
-adult day programs for seniors who live in the community will not be allowed
-25 people, down from 50, can gather with physical distancing for informal indoor and outdoor social events like a neighbourhood street party
-indoor events run by a recognized business or organization can have 50 per cent of the venue’s capacity to 
a maximum of 100 people with physical distancing, down from 200
-outdoor events run by a recognized business or organization can have 150 people with physical distancing, down from 250
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

Require ferries and essential passenger vessel operators to:

description:
Canada, Quebec, April 15 "THAT in addition to the visits authorized by Ministerial Order 2020- 009 dated 23 March 2020, visits from a family caregiver to users lodged in facilities in institutions where a residential and long-term care centre is operated be authorized if the following conditions are met:
(1) the user was receiving support from the family caregiver before
13 March 2020 and that support is still necessary;
(2) the family caregiver
(a) understands the risks inherent in the visits;
(b) undertakes to respect the directives given by the institution and
the public health authorities; and
(c) received a negative COVID-19 screening result before the first
visit and shows no COVID-19 related symptoms;
(3) the director of public health for the region in which the institution
is situated has not ordered the visits suspended to protect the health of the
population" UPDATE: Update of the policy concerning visitors to long term care facilities

description: Canada, April 17, 2020 "Today, the Minister of Transport, the Honourable Marc Garneau, announced new measures requiring all air passengers to have a non-medical mask or face covering to cover their mouth and nose during travel. These measures come into effect at noon EDT on April 20, 2020 and will be in place until further notice. When travelling by air, travellers will be asked to cover their mouth and nose: at Canadian airport screening checkpoints, where the screeners cannot always keep two metres of separation between themselves and the traveller; when they cannot physically distance from others, or as directed by the airline employees; and when directed to do so by a public health order or public health official."

description: Can, NB, May 11, 2020 "Dr. Jennifer Russell, chief medical officer of health, announced new rules for visiting patients nearing the end of their lives in hospitals, nursing homes and hospices. Patients will be permitted to designate two visitors to provide comfort and support. The two individuals selected will be the only visitors permitted and only one visitor is permitted at a time. No substitutions will be permitted. If a designated visitor, such as a frail, elderly spouse or person with a disability, requires a second person to support them, this person would count as the second chosen visitor. All designated visitors: Will be required to maintain physical distancing and limit their interactions with facility staff and the public, must leave the patient’s room when staff are conducting procedures, must monitor themselves for symptoms of COVID-19 and refrain from visiting should symptoms appear, must follow facility rules regarding infection control for other viruses, such as influenza and the common cold"

UPDATE: Phase 1: “Double bubble" - close contact is allowed between members of 2 households. For both indoor and outdoor social gatherings, 10 people or fewer are allowed. description:
Canada, NS, March 15th "Long term care facilities will be closed for visitors" UPDATE: On July 17th the gov of NS, Canada stated that "Changes to the province’s directive to long-term care homes will allow for more visitors outdoors, limited indoor visits, and some return to activities. Effective July 22, the following changes can be implemented by long-term care facilities:

both indoor and outdoor visits will be allowed with limited numbers of visitors and scheduled appointments. Residents and visitors must wear masks and observe physical distancing, except for limited physical contact like a hug
residents and staff can gather in groups of 10 or less for dining, recreation or socializing without physical distancing. Groups should remain consistent and visitors cannot join
sightseeing bus trips for groups of up to 10 people (including residents, staff and driver) are allowed. Residents and staff cannot get off the bus and thorough cleaning before and after each trip is required
licensed hair salons within long-term care homes can reopen to serve residents only"
Gov. of Alberta, Canada has issued updates to visitation guideline for  how long term care facilities visits will work. Date is 23. July.

description: Canada, April 17, 2020 "Today, the Minister of Transport, the Honourable Marc Garneau, announced new measures requiring all air passengers to have a non-medical mask or face covering to cover their mouth and nose during travel. These measures come into effect at noon EDT on April 20, 2020 and will be in place until further notice. When travelling by air, travellers will be asked to cover their mouth and nose: at Canadian airport screening checkpoints, where the screeners cannot always keep two metres of separation between themselves and the traveller; when they cannot physically distance from others, or as directed by the airline employees; and when directed to do so by a public health order or public health official." UPDATE: On August 7, 2020, Transport Canada closed a loophole in the April 20, 2020 policy stating that all passengers who are unable to wear a face mask due to a medical condition must now present an official doctor's note stating that they are exempt from the rule, or they will be denied boarding.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Canada, NB, April 13 "Steps taken to protect residents living in nursing homes include: 1. Not allowing visitors.2. description:
Students in Kindergarten to Grade 12 will return to the classroom full-time in Manitoba on September 7.
Students in K-6 will continue to be grouped into cohorts to begin the year, while students in Grades 7-12 won’t be placed into cohorts.
Masks are mandatory for all.
Recesses and lunch breaks will continue to be staggered.
Assigned seating on school buses will remain to help with social distancing and contact tracing.
Educational workers are required to get first dose by Sept. 7 and to either get fully vaccinated by Oct. 17 or be regularly tested for COVID-19
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: February 3, 2020: With Bulletin N. 42, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, attended a summit between G7 Health Ministers on COVID-19. Health Ministers include: Patricia A. Hajdu for Canada, Agnès Buzyn for France, Jens Spahn for Germany, Kato Katsunobu for Japan, Matt Hancock for the UK and Alex Michael Azar II for the US. The aim of the conference was to share information between Health Ministries of the G7. Updates about the trend of the pandemic and the epidemiological situation in each State were discussed. The Italian Minister of Health outlined to the G7 colleagues the measures taken by Italy, for example the ban of flights from China and health monitoring in ports and airports. The meeting also discussed the importance of a communal commitment to support the Chinese government in its efforts to address the emergency and underlined the need to collaborate and share all scientific information useful to fight COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: February 12, 2020: With Bulletin N. 65, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, attended a teleconference between G7 Health Ministers on COVID-19 (Countries within the G7 include: Italy, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, USA and UK). The aim of the conference was to share information between Health Ministries of the G7. During the conference, updates were provided on the state of the epidemic in each State and on the measures taken by each State. Possible future scenarios were also examined. Finally, the Ministers discussed the procedures for the exchange of biological material in order to share all the information in the field of scientific research.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)

description: April 3, 2020: With Bulletin N. 135, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, attended a summit with G7 Health Ministers on COVID-19 (Countries within the G7 include: Italy, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, USA and UK). The aim of the conference was to share information about the COVID-19 health crisis between Health Ministries of the G7. During the conference, updates were provided on the state of the epidemic in each country and on the measures taken by each State. During the meeting, a common problem that emerge was the need to improve the validation of serological tests and the use of the most modern technologies for 'fast tracking'. The Italian Minister said that the G7 countries need a common approach to the same issues and that international collaboration is vital.

The meeting also discussed the fight against microbial antibiotic resistance, with a particular focus on the situation of the COVID-19 pandemic and the new emerging strains.

description: March 29, 2021: With Bulletin N. 14, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza has attended a meeting with G7 Health Ministers. The aim of the meeting was to discuss the COVID-19 digital health and vaccination certificate, both at European level and on a global scale. Minister Speranza stated that it is important to discuss a "green pass", and reach a solution before summer 2021 in order to allow safe travel between countries.

description: April 23, 2021: With Bulletin N. 16, the Italian Ministry of Health has announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended a summit with Health Ministers of the G7. The aim of the meeting was to discuss and share information about the COVID-19 pandemic, and to provide updates about the situation in each country. Furthermore, the meeting discussed the "Green Pass Project", which relates to matters of safe travel and tourism for the coming summer. Minister Speranza has underlined the importance of international cooperation and coordination between countries, over the measures the combat the pandemic.
